acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 96 hours LC50=2.14mg/L of the crustacea (Penaeus Chinensis) (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report, 2004).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 750mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 750mg/kg (SIDS (2002)) and 1,722mg/kg (SIDS (2002)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 433mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 530mg/kg (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), 294mg/kg (SIDS (2002)), 565mg/kg (SIDS (2002)), 664mg/kg (SIDS (2002)) and 694mg/kg (SIDS (2002)).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classified into Category 3 by IARC (1996), and into Category A3 by ACGIH (2001); priority is given to the latest evaluation document according to the guidelines.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Although acute toxicity was Category 2 and the bio-accumulation potential was low (BCF=20.9(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), since there was no rapidly degrading (the decomposition by BOD: 0%(Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)), it was classified into Category 2.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing nitro groups, with the oxygen budget calculated at -122. However, No data available on kick-off temperatures and decomposition energy. Not classified, based on the classification by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (Division 6.1, UN#1578)

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#1578)

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on germ cell multi-generation mutagenicity tests and mutagenicity tests in vivo, positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests) and the absence of data on germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, described in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.57 (2004).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: No data available, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen. Not classified, based on the classification by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (Division 6.1, UN#1578)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, UN#1578)

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: Based on the description in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.57 (2004) and SIDS (2005): Continuous breeding studies in mice indicate a significant decrease in conception rates; rat teratogenicity tests indicate skeletal malformations (mainly curbed ribs) in offspring at dosing levels toxic to dams; repeated inhalation exposure in rats and mice results in spermatogenic disorder, shorter sexual cycles (rats) and longer sexual cycles (mice).

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available - melting point: 82-84degC (ICSC, 1999), test temperature: 140degC

self_reactive_substances.rationale: No data available, though containing nitro groups. Not classified, based on the classification by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (Division 6.1, UN#1578)

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in the report on rabbit eye irritation tests (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.57 (2005)): The substance causes mild irritation, if any, to the eyes.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (blood, testis)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence from animal studies including "cyanosis, an increase in methemoglobin concentrations, a decrease in red blood cell count, a decrease in hematocrit/hemoglobin values, an increase in the absolute/relative weight of the spleen, splenic hypertrophy, splenic extramedullary hematopoiesis, hemosiderin deposition, bone marrow hyperplasia, a decrease in spermatid count and sperm concentrations, impaired sperm mobility, testis atrophy, seminiferous tubule atrophy" (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.57 (2004)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the description in CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.57 (2004): hemolytic anemia due to methemoglobin formation, and cyanosis are observed in human cases.
